content.question: Let <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be differentiable functions such that <math alttext="f prime of 1, equals 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="g prime of 1, equals 6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. If <math alttext="h of x equals, 5 times f of x, minus 4 times g of x, plus 3 times x squared, minus 2," display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, what is the value of <math alttext="h prime of 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

topic.text: 2.6: Derivative Rules - Constant, Sum, Difference, and Constant Multiple

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
